overview_of_class:
This course will give students without a software development background a hands-on immersion in the toolsets, processes, and programming languages used in the development of web properties.
The goal of the class is to prepare non-developers to work successfully with developers - to learn what they need to know to collaborate with technologists on a day-to-day basis.? Working in small teams in an agile software development environment, students will work with version control tools, collaborative programming, front-end web development languages (HTML, CSS, Javascript), and frameworks including SASS, JQuery, React, Ember and Angular.

subject: JOUR

overview_of_class: This course focuses on imparting methods, theory, and practical experience in the field of design research in order to help define innovative products, services, and businesses in media and journalism. Students will be exposed to interviewing and observational techniques from anthropology, psychology, and sociology; interpretive techniques from literature, psychology, and business strategy; and creative methods and prototyping techniques from engineering, design, marketing, and advertising. By the end of this course, students will have a firm grounding in how to study a small number of people, uncover patterns in their thinking and behavior that point to design opportunities for news media products and services, and understand how to quickly test and improve ideas that solve for these opportunities. This course has roots in, and a similar arc to, fundamental design research courses taught in major design programs, inside major corporations, by influential consultancies, and in the most prominent startup accelerator, Matter Ventures.

subject: JOUR

overview_of_class: For one full quarter, students will work two or three days a week at a Bay Area company, focused on building media/tech products and/or making them more successful. The goal is for students to get hands-on experience that helps them develop new skills, sharpen existing ones and develop a deeper understanding of media innovation and product development. Students will file weekly reflections on their internships and meet several times during the quarter with the professor and other students to discuss their experiences. Each student will be expected to present once to the group about their experiences and/or lessons learned, and to write a reflective assessment at the end of the quarter about what they learned from the internship.

overview_of_class: Students will explore innovation and business opportunities in the center of the world's technology industry. Starting with business fundamentals in media and technology industries, they will learn to recognize opportunities for disruption, assess the competitive landscape, and evaluate innovation strategies. For the product ideas they are developing, they will identify possible business models that would make them sustainable. The course aims to inspire students to be the force of innovation in media technology companies of any size, from the start-up venture to the conglomerate.

overview_of_class: Politics lie at the heart of the most important social issues of our time, from health care and immigration policy to housing, guns, climate change, racial and gender inequality, reproductive rights and the widening gulf between the haves and have-nots. Not only do electoral campaigns influence policy, but so do grassroots and astroturf projects and the permanent campaigns of such interest groups as the NRA, Americans for Prosperity, Planned Parenthood and the Sierra Club. This seminar focuses on the politics of social policy, including the 2018 campaign, with particular attention to the competition between supporters and progressive opponents of Donald Trump. In this course, expect to build topical expertise and critical thinking skills along with rigorous reporting techniques.
